texts.label: text
texts.orig: Cultural note: In Austria we usually consider voting both a right and a responsibility. There's an old Austrian slogan " Wer nicht wählen geht, der wählt automatisch die falschen "   ('Who   doesn't   vote   is automatically voting for the wrong ones'), often cited to nudge everyone to participate. That about sums it up: even if we're grumpy about politics, we show up at the polls. It's ingrained that Sunday voting ritual - some even bring along their dog (ties him outside) or their kids (to teach them early). And when the results come, if we're unhappy, well, at least we know we had our say. Then we move on with our lives, maybe making a joke like " Naja, nächstes Mal haben wir wieder die Chance " ('Well, next time we have the chance again'). Democracy, Austrian-style: a mix of earnestness, cake, and a pragmatically raised eyebrow. 🗳

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Topic: Unemployment benefits (AMS & Arbeitslosengeld)
texts.text: Topic: Unemployment benefits (AMS & Arbeitslosengeld)

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Losing a job is tough, but in Austria there's a safety net to help you get by while you search for the next gig. It's managed by the AMS (Arbeitsmarktservice - the job market service) and comes in the form of Arbeitslosengeld (unemployment benefits). Who can get this? Anyone who had been working and paying into the unemployment insurance system (which is basically every employee; it's automatic) and then loses their job or quits for a valid reason. You also need to have worked a minimum amount (usually at least 52 weeks in the last 2 years) to qualify, especially if it's your first time claiming.
texts.text: Losing a job is tough, but in Austria there's a safety net to help you get by while you search for the next gig. It's managed by the AMS (Arbeitsmarktservice - the job market service) and comes in the form of Arbeitslosengeld (unemployment benefits). Who can get this? Anyone who had been working and paying into the unemployment insurance system (which is basically every employee; it's automatic) and then loses their job or quits for a valid reason. You also need to have worked a minimum amount (usually at least 52 weeks in the last 2 years) to qualify, especially if it's your first time claiming.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Official process: The key is to register with the AMS as soon as you become unemployed. Ideally, if you know your job will end on date X, you go to the AMS office a few days before or on that day to register as arbeitssuchend (job-seeking). At the latest, do it on your first day of unemployment - delay can cost you benefits for those days. You can go in person to the AMS or, nowadays, do much of it online via eAMS (the AMS portal). You provide your e-card number (social security number), personal data, and details of your employment history. You'll need an ID and your Arbeitsbescheinigung or Dienstzeugnis (a form or certificate from your last employer confirming your employment and its end). If you were on a limited contract that just ended, or got laid off, or even if you quit (you usually still get benefits, though quitting without good reason can lead to a four-week penalty of no pay at start), you are eligible.
texts.text: Official process: The key is to register with the AMS as soon as you become unemployed. Ideally, if you know your job will end on date X, you go to the AMS office a few days before or on that day to register as arbeitssuchend (job-seeking). At the latest, do it on your first day of unemployment - delay can cost you benefits for those days. You can go in person to the AMS or, nowadays, do much of it online via eAMS (the AMS portal). You provide your e-card number (social security number), personal data, and details of your employment history. You'll need an ID and your Arbeitsbescheinigung or Dienstzeugnis (a form or certificate from your last employer confirming your employment and its end). If you were on a limited contract that just ended, or got laid off, or even if you quit (you usually still get benefits, though quitting without good reason can lead to a four-week penalty of no pay at start), you are eligible.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Then you fill out the Antrag auf Arbeitslosengeld (application for unemployment benefits). This form asks about any other income, dependents (for potential small extra allowances), etc. The AMS clerk or the online system calculates your benefit amount. Typically it's about 55% of your previous net income (there's a daily rate they compute). If you had a very low income, there's a minimum amount; if very high, a maximum cap. The benefit duration depends on how long you've worked in recent years and your age - younger folks might get 20 weeks, while older workers with long work histories can get up to a year of benefits.
texts.text: Then you fill out the Antrag auf Arbeitslosengeld (application for unemployment benefits). This form asks about any other income, dependents (for potential small extra allowances), etc. The AMS clerk or the online system calculates your benefit amount. Typically it's about 55% of your previous net income (there's a daily rate they compute). If you had a very low income, there's a minimum amount; if very high, a maximum cap. The benefit duration depends on how long you've worked in recent years and your age - younger folks might get 20 weeks, while older workers with long work histories can get up to a year of benefits.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Once that's sorted, the AMS effectively becomes your job coach (and watchdog). They assign you an advisor and an Betreuungsplan (support plan). You have to check in regularly, either by coming to the office for a meeting or increasingly by phone/online. You're required to actively seek work - writing applications, going to interviews. The AMS can ask for proof of that (like copies of applications). They'll also send you Stellenvorschläge (job suggestions). If the AMS sends you to an interview for a job that is deemed zumutbar (reasonable for you), you should go - refusing a suitable job or not applying can lead to a cut in benefits (called a Sperre , a lockout, usually 6 weeks no pay for the first offense).
texts.text: Once that's sorted, the AMS effectively becomes your job coach (and watchdog). They assign you an advisor and an Betreuungsplan (support plan). You have to check in regularly, either by coming to the office for a meeting or increasingly by phone/online. You're required to actively seek work - writing applications, going to interviews. The AMS can ask for proof of that (like copies of applications). They'll also send you Stellenvorschläge (job suggestions). If the AMS sends you to an interview for a job that is deemed zumutbar (reasonable for you), you should go - refusing a suitable job or not applying can lead to a cut in benefits (called a Sperre , a lockout, usually 6 weeks no pay for the first offense).

texts.label: text
texts.orig: They might also enroll you in courses: common ones are IT skills, German classes for non-natives, or Bewerbungstraining (how to apply training) where they fine-tune your CV and interview skills. Some of these courses are very useful, some less so (hence jokes like 'I learned how to hold a pencil in AMS training, sigh'). But hey, it's free and can add structure to your day.
texts.text: They might also enroll you in courses: common ones are IT skills, German classes for non-natives, or Bewerbungstraining (how to apply training) where they fine-tune your CV and interview skills. Some of these courses are very useful, some less so (hence jokes like 'I learned how to hold a pencil in AMS training, sigh'). But hey, it's free and can add structure to your day.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: If you run through your entitlement period without finding a job, you can apply for Notstandshilfe (emergency assistance). This is a bit lower than the initial benefit (like 92% of it if single, less if you have partner income) and is means-tested to some degree. But it's renewable indefinitely in 6-month blocks, so nobody completely falls through - as long as you engage with AMS, you won't be left with nothing.
texts.text: If you run through your entitlement period without finding a job, you can apply for Notstandshilfe (emergency assistance). This is a bit lower than the initial benefit (like 92% of it if single, less if you have partner income) and is means-tested to some degree. But it's renewable indefinitely in 6-month blocks, so nobody completely falls through - as long as you engage with AMS, you won't be left with nothing.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: How do Austrians usually handle this emotionally and practically? There's not too much stigma in saying "Ich bin arbeitslos gerade" (I'm unemployed right now). It happens, especially with seasonal work or short contracts. People do feel the pressure, though - Austrians are generally diligent and being jobless can feel disconcerting, so structure helps: they'll joke that the AMS is their new boss. "Muss morgen zum AMS, präsent sein" ('Gotta be at AMS tomorrow, be present'), they'll say as if it's a work meeting. The

"Muss morgen zum AMS, präsent sein" ('Gotta be at AMS tomorrow, be present'), they'll say as if it's a work meeting. The

texts.label: text
texts.orig: AMS office waiting area is a mix: some anxious faces, some bored ones scrolling their phones, and an array of people from every profession - it's a great equalizer .
texts.text: AMS office waiting area is a mix: some anxious faces, some bored ones scrolling their phones, and an array of people from every profession - it's a great equalizer .

texts.label: text
texts.orig: At home, many treat job hunting like a 9-to-5: sending out emails, checking job platforms (AMS has a job   database,   as   does   karriere.at   and   others).   If   too   much   time   passes,   one   might   consider Umschulung (retraining) - the AMS can fund long courses or apprenticeships for in-demand fields. It's not uncommon for someone to say, " Ich mach über's AMS jetzt einen Kurs zur Pflegeassistenz " ('I'm doing a course via AMS now to become a nursing assistant') if their old industry had no jobs.

If   too   much   time   passes,   one   might   consider Umschulung (retraining) - the AMS can fund long courses or apprenticeships for in-demand fields. It's not uncommon for someone to say, " Ich mach über's AMS jetzt einen Kurs zur Pflegeassistenz " ('I'm doing a course via AMS now to become a nursing assistant') if their old industry had no jobs.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Culturally, Austrians appreciate that the system is there. The attitude is often, " Hab ja eingezahlt, jetzt krieg ich was raus " ('I paid in, now I get something out'), meaning since we all contribute via insurance deductions from salary, it's seen as your right to draw benefits when needed. There's also a generally sympathetic view towards the unemployed; you'll seldom hear harsh "get a job" rhetoric in mainstream conversation - rather, people blame the economy or companies. In fact, the term 'Sozialstaat' (social state) is often used positively - we're proud of our welfare system.

The attitude is often, " Hab ja eingezahlt, jetzt krieg ich was raus " ('I paid in, now I get something out'), meaning since we all contribute via insurance deductions from salary, it's seen as your right to draw benefits when needed. There's also a generally sympathetic view towards the unemployed; you'll seldom hear harsh "get a job" rhetoric in mainstream conversation - rather, people blame the economy or companies. In fact, the term 'Sozialstaat' (social state) is often used positively - we're proud of our welfare system.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Of course, we do also poke fun at the AMS experience. There's a famous satire song 'Arbeitslos durch den Tag' ('Unemployed through the day') which jokingly describes a day of someone on benefits doing nothing - but it's tongue-in-cheek. Most unemployed Austrians keep themselves busy and genuinely want to work.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: And one must mention: each year the AMS actually sends out surveys to unemployed folks to evaluate their services. So the unemployed get to review their "boss" - how very Austrian! Often, they'll share these surveys in forums: " Hab den AMS-Berater 2 von 5 Sternen gegeben, weil er mir nur Zeitarbeit angeboten hat. " ('I gave the AMS advisor 2 out of 5 stars because he only offered me temp jobs.') - we do love our feedback loops.

" ('I gave the AMS advisor 2 out of 5 stars because he only offered me temp jobs.') - we do love our feedback loops.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: In a nutshell, being unemployed in Austria is not the end of the world financially, thanks to the AMS, but it does become a sort of job in itself to navigate the system and keep spirits up. People often encourage each other saying " Kopf hoch, du findest bald was " ('Chin up, you'll find something soon'). And usually, with Austria's still-healthy job market, that turns out true.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Cultural note: In   Austria   we   usually  regard the unemployed with empathy rather than judgment. There's an underlying belief in giving people support to bounce back. It's baked into our social system.
texts.text: Cultural note: In   Austria   we   usually  regard the unemployed with empathy rather than judgment. There's an underlying belief in giving people support to bounce back. It's baked into our social system.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: So, while someone might jokingly call themselves " AMSler " (AMS-er) during that period, they know it's temporary and they're still very much a part of society. And Austrians do something interesting - they often continue hobbies or even start new education during unemployment (especially if the AMS isn't too demanding that week). It's not all gloom. Some say, " Nutz die Zeit, wennst kan Job hast, zum Radfahren/Weiterbilden " ('Use the time when you don't have a job to cycle/educate yourself further'). So you'll see unemployed folks at the library improving their English or out jogging at 10am to clear their head. It's a pragmatic approach: stay active, stay hopeful. Because as we often remind each other , " Die Wirtschaft sucht eh wieder Leute " ('The economy is always looking for people again soon'). And that optimism - coupled with the AMS safety net - helps many get through a tough chapter with dignity intact.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Topic: School enrollment (Schuleinschreibung)
texts.text: Topic: School enrollment (Schuleinschreibung)

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Starting school is a big moment for kids and parents alike. In Austria, education is compulsory from age 6   onwards   (that's   when Volksschule ,   primary   school,   begins).   Who   needs   to   worry   about   school enrollment? If you have a child approaching school age - or if you move to Austria with school-aged kids - you'll be dealing with the Schuleinschreibung (school registration process) to get them into the education system.
texts.text: Starting school is a big moment for kids and parents alike. In Austria, education is compulsory from age 6   onwards   (that's   when Volksschule ,   primary   school,   begins).   Who   needs   to   worry   about   school enrollment? If you have a child approaching school age - or if you move to Austria with school-aged kids - you'll be dealing with the Schuleinschreibung (school registration process) to get them into the education system.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Official process: The year a child turns 6 (if by September 1st they are six years old), they are due to start primary school that autumn. Typically, each neighborhood has a local public primary school you're zoned to. In the winter or early spring before that school year (usually Jan/Feb), there's an enrollment period. You'll   either   receive   a   letter   from   the   city   school   board   or   see   notices,   but   you   can   also proactively contact your local school. You (usually Mom or Dad) and the child will go to the school on a designated Einschreibung day.
texts.text: Official process: The year a child turns 6 (if by September 1st they are six years old), they are due to start primary school that autumn. Typically, each neighborhood has a local public primary school you're zoned to. In the winter or early spring before that school year (usually Jan/Feb), there's an enrollment period. You'll   either   receive   a   letter   from   the   city   school   board   or   see   notices,   but   you   can   also proactively contact your local school. You (usually Mom or Dad) and the child will go to the school on a designated Einschreibung day.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: You bring: the child's Geburtsurkunde (birth certificate), their Meldezettel (residence registration - to prove you live in the school's district), your own ID, and if applicable the Heiratsurkunde (marriage certificate of parents) or a Nachweis der Obsorge (proof of custody) if you have a different last name or a special situation. Also, if your child attended Kindergarten, sometimes a little developmental report from the Kindergarten is asked for , but not always.
texts.text: You bring: the child's Geburtsurkunde (birth certificate), their Meldezettel (residence registration - to prove you live in the school's district), your own ID, and if applicable the Heiratsurkunde (marriage certificate of parents) or a Nachweis der Obsorge (proof of custody) if you have a different last name or a special situation. Also, if your child attended Kindergarten, sometimes a little developmental report from the Kindergarten is asked for , but not always.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: At the school, it's quite friendly. The child might go with a teacher for a few minutes for a little 'readiness' assessment - nothing stressful, maybe identifying colors, drawing something, hopping on one foot, etc., just to gauge if they're school-ready. Almost all kids are; only in rare cases if a child just turned 6 and is clearly not ready socially or motor-skills-wise, the parents might be advised to wait another year (that's called 'Schulreif noch nicht gegeben' - not yet school-ready). But again, rare.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Meanwhile, the admin or principal will have you fill out forms with your and the child's data, any special considerations (religion for the optional religion class, any allergies or special needs), and whether you consent to things like photo usage, etc. You also indicate if you want the child in Nachmittagsbetreuung (afternoon care) if the school offers it - Austrian primary schools often end by 12 or 1 pm, but many have optional care until about 4 or 5 pm for working parents, which you'd sign up for here.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: If there's any question of district - say you want a different school than your assigned one - you actually still enroll at your assigned school but also file a request with the education board for a transfer . They'll allocate extra spots around May/June. If your child has an older sibling at a different school, they usually allow them to go there too.
texts.text: If there's any question of district - say you want a different school than your assigned one - you actually still enroll at your assigned school but also file a request with the education board for a transfer . They'll allocate extra spots around May/June. If your child has an older sibling at a different school, they usually allow them to go there too.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: After enrollment, you'll get a confirmation and later (in June or so) an official Schulplatz-Bestätigung (school place confirmation) telling you exactly where your child will start in fall (if you applied for a different school, this is when you know if it worked out).

texts.label: text
texts.orig: How do Austrians usually handle school enrollment? Fairly calmly for primary school, with a dash of sentimentality (' Mein Baby kommt in die Schule! ' - 'My baby is starting school!'). Parents might chat with other parents about which teacher is good, or whether the school has a focus (some have bilingual classes or Montessor some parents get a bit anxious: "Gymnasium oder Mittelschule?" (Academic high school or general middle school?) becomes a hot topic during 4th grade. But ultimately, every child finds a place in the education system, and parents learn that there are many paths through schooling. By the time school actually starts, nerves give way to excitement - the big first day is full of Schultüte (school cone) treats, new backpacks, and proud family members snapping photos. It's a milestone that Austrians cherish, and from that point on, die Schule geht los ('school is underway') and a new chapter begins.

texts.orig: German keywords: Schuleinschreibung (school enrollment/registration), Volksschule (primary school), Gymnasium (academic secondary school), Mittelschule (general secondary school), Schultüte (school cone filled with goodies).

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Example dialogue: Parent: "Guten Tag, wir möchten unsere Tochter für die Volksschule anmelden." (Hello, we'd like to enroll our daughter in primary school.)
texts.text: Example dialogue: Parent: "Guten Tag, wir möchten unsere Tochter für die Volksschule anmelden." (Hello, we'd like to enroll our daughter in primary school.)

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Secretary: "Gerne. Wie heißt Ihre Tochter und wann ist ihr Geburtstag?" (Sure. What is your daughter's name and when is her birthday?)
texts.text: Secretary: "Gerne. Wie heißt Ihre Tochter und wann ist ihr Geburtstag?" (Sure. What is your daughter's name and when is her birthday?)

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Parent: "Sie heißt Lea Müller, geboren am 5. April 2018." (Her name is Lea Müller , born April 5, 2018.)
texts.text: Parent: "Sie heißt Lea Müller, geboren am 5. April 2018." (Her name is Lea Müller , born April 5, 2018.)

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Secretary: "Alles klar. Darf ich Ihren Meldezettel sehen? Und die Geburtsurkunde von Lea?" (Alright. May I see your registration form? And Lea's birth certificate?)
texts.text: Secretary: "Alles klar. Darf ich Ihren Meldezettel sehen? Und die Geburtsurkunde von Lea?" (Alright. May I see your registration form? And Lea's birth certificate?)

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Parent: "Ja, bitteschön." (Yes, here you go.)
texts.text: Parent: "Ja, bitteschön." (Yes, here you go.)

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Secretary: "Danke. Möchten Sie Nachmittagsbetreuung anmelden?" (Thanks. Do you want to sign up for afternoon care?)
texts.text: Secretary: "Danke. Möchten Sie Nachmittagsbetreuung anmelden?" (Thanks. Do you want to sign up for afternoon care?)

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Parent: "Ja, an den Tagen Montag bis Donnerstag gerne." (Yes, on Monday through Thursday, please.)
texts.text: Parent: "Ja, an den Tagen Montag bis Donnerstag gerne." (Yes, on Monday through Thursday, please.)

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Secretary: "In Ordnung, das notiere ich. Dann sind wir fertig - Lea ist jetzt vorgemerkt. Sie bekommen im Juni Post mit allen Details." (Alright, I'll note that. That's it - Lea is now registered. You'll get mail in June with all the details.)
texts.text: Secretary: "In Ordnung, das notiere ich. Dann sind wir fertig - Lea ist jetzt vorgemerkt. Sie bekommen im Juni Post mit allen Details." (Alright, I'll note that. That's it - Lea is now registered. You'll get mail in June with all the details.)

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Parent: "Super, dankeschön!" (Great, thank you very much!)
texts.text: Parent: "Super, dankeschön!" (Great, thank you very much!)

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Cultural note: In Austria we usually take a friendly, no-fuss approach to school enrollment. Most people here prefer the neighborhood school, and there's a sense of community as kids from the same Grätzl (local area) grow up together. The first day of school is a big milestone - expect proud grandparents, photos with the new Schulranzen (school backpack), and plenty of " Alles Gute zum Schulstart! " ('All the best for starting school!') wishes going around. It's both an ending (no more baby!) and a beginning (little kid on a big adventure), and Austrians mark it with equal parts efficiency (forms done, check) and heartwarming tradition (that school cone and maybe a special family cake after the first day). School, here we come! 📚
